ref_text: As NSA, he assisted Carter in diplomatically handling world affairs, such as the Camp David Accords, 1978; normalizing US–China relations thought the late 1970s; the Iranian Revolution, which led to the Iran hostage crisis, 1979; and the Soviet invasion in Afghanistan, 1979.
hyp_text: Carter, a former governor of Georgia, was elected President in 1976. His administration was marked by several major crises, including the 1979 Iranian hostage crisis, the 1979 energy crisis, the Three Mile Island nuclear accident, and the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. In response to the Soviet move he ended détente, escalated the Cold War military buildup and placed an embargo on grain shipments to the USSR. The end of détente also resulted in the end of the SALT II treaty. In 1977 he brokered a peace agreement between Israel and Egypt at the Camp David Accords. The U.S. House of Representatives later approved the Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty which was signed in 1979. He won the 1976 election, running as an outsider and a reformer. Once in office he added to his popularity by granting amnesty to Vietnam War draft dodgers, but he also disappointed some followers with his policies on issues such as taxes and energy. His reorganization efforts were frustrated by the federal bureaucracy and congressional Democrats. He was attacked for his handling of the economy, and for the rescue of American hostages in Iran. His campaign for re-election was one of the most humiliating in history, as he lost 44 of 50 states in Reagan's 1980 landslide. His post-presidential career was one of the most successful in history, winning the Nobel Peace Prize in 2002 for his humanitarian work. In polls of historians and political scientists, Carter is usually ranked as a below-average President.
